The discovery of titanium silicalite-1(TS-1) is a milestone in the development of heterogeneous catalysts for the eco-benign and mild catalytic oxidation process. However, the interpretation of specific Ti location and its role in oxidation is severely hindered due to the limited crystal size of as-synthesized TS-1. Here, a high quality TS-1 (ca. 10 μm) was successfully fabricated by the pre-hydrolysis silica source strategy. As evidenced by powder X-ray diffraction crystallography, the preferred Ti locations were mainly found at T2, T4, and T11 in Ti-containing MFI framework. Combining multiple spectroscopy methods (i.e., FT-IR, UV–Vis, and UV Raman) and the reaction kinetics, the active center in TS-1 was demonstrated as an exposed site of hexa-coordinated titainum species. Furthermore, the powder X-ray crystallography also revealed that the ketone and oxime adsorbed in the zeolite host with intense host-guest interaction of framework oxygen atoms, and exhibiting an overwhelming spatial intimacy to the Ti species at the molecular scale. This unique phenomenon affords a plausible interpretation for the oxime reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Titanium silicalite-1 Ti location Ammoximation reaction Rietveld refinement Host-guest chemistry 1 Introduction Oxime and its derivatives are valuable intermediates in the medical and chemical industries. The ammoximation of cyclohexanone is the key process to fabricate cyclohexanone oxime, which is a crucial compound in the production of caprolactam. However, in the early days, this reaction was usually carried out under a homogenous, acid-catalysis procedure and generated a vast amount of inorganic wastes [1,2]. Due to the shortcoming of the conventional methods, a highly efficient and eco-friendly strategy is strongly desired. In the 1980s, an innovative strategy is proposed to fabricate oxime using TS-1 catalyst [3] with the presence of ammonia and H2O2 under mild conditions. Zeolite, a classical porous inorganic aluminosilicate, is constructed by numerous SiO4 and/or AlO4 tetrahedrons by sharing the vertex oxygen atom. The structure, which exhibits well-ordered channel systems with limited size in molecular scale, has always been extensively used in detergents [4], gas adsorption/separation [5–7], and catalysts [8,9]. Generally, the tetrahedron (T) atom in the zeolite framework can be replaced by other elements (Ti, Fe, Mn, etc.) to endow desirable properties. For example, the incorporation of Ti atom into the pure siliceous MFI (three-letter framework type code assigned by international zeolite association) structure leads to the discovery of titanium silicalite-1 (TS-1). In the last four decades, the TS-1 has already shown excellent performance in the field of partial oxidations in the mild oxidation process with H2O2. TS-1, as the core in the cyclohexanone ammoxidation process, great efforts have been devoted to exploring the active sites and corresponding catalytic mechanisms. The coordination status of the Ti species is usually revealed by spectroscopy methods, such as FT-IR [10–12], UV–Vis [13], UV Raman [13–16], NMR [17–22], XAFS [23–27], or theoretical calculations [20,26,28,29]. However, the specific locations of Ti atoms in the MFI unit cell (twelve T atoms in an asymmetry unit) remain elusive for structural complexity. Hence, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) crystallography [30,31], and neutron powder diffraction [32] have been introduced to solve this key issue. It was found that the Ti atom incorporated in the MFI framework is mainly located at T6, T7, T10, and T11 [32]. Also, the active species in the real catalytic cycle are studied by spectroscopy [11,12,33-37] and computational methods [28,29,38]. Usually, the TS-1 was synthesized with silica, titanium source, and TPAOH without any inorganic alkali cations in a hydrothermal system [3,39,40]. The obtained TS-1 always presents a small crystal size (200–500 nm) [41–43] with limited crystal quality [44–46]. It is worth noting that the precise interpretation of Ti locations and their nature in the catalytic reactions is significantly impeded by the limited crystal size. Thus, the location of Ti sites in the MFI framework and its “structure-function” relationship in oxime reaction is yet to be clarified. Inspired by previous reports, in this work, a series of large crystal-sized TS-1 were synthesized using the pre-hydrolysis silica source strategy [47]. The titanium locations in the framework and its coordination status are unveiled by PXRD Rietveld refinement, FT-IR, UV–Vis, and UV Raman techniques. The Ti sites in TS-1 were preferentially located at T2, T4, and T11, which is distinct from the sites of T4, T7, and T12 found in Na_TS-1. The mechanism of cyclohexanone oxime reaction over such TS-1 was monitored as well. The reactants and obtained guest species occluded in the TS-1 were confirmed by solid-state NMR and powder X-ray crystallography. We showed that the cyclohexanone and oxime were located in the TS-1 void with intense host-guest interaction of framework oxygen atoms, which exhibited an overwhelming spatial intimacy to the Ti species. This unique phenomenon unveiled here would afford a plausible interpretation for the oxime reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of TS-1 and Na_TS-1 The organic structure-directing agent (OSDA) tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) solution (25% wt.) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent and used directly. Generally, by a conventional procedure, the TS-1 synthesized in a sodium-free system always exhibited insufficient crystallites (∼200 nm), which hindered futher precisely crystallographic analysis of the corresponding substandard PXRD data. In this work, we found that the micro-sized TS-1 crystallites can be readily acquired by pre-hydrolysis of silica source strategy. Prior to the experiment, the silica source was obtained by pre-hydrolysis of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) in the presence of TPAOH by the following recipe: 1 TEOS: 3 C2H5OH: 10 H2O: 0.01 TPAOH [47]. Then, the silica source was recovered by calcined at 723 K in the air for 6 h. In a typical synthesis procedure, the calculated silica source, sodium hydroxide, TPAOH, titanium (IV) isopropoxide, and deionized water were mixed sequentially. After vigorous stirring overnight, the final milky gel with a general composition: 1 SiO2 : 0.225 TPAOH : x Ti(C3H7O)4: 30 H2O. (0.01≤ x ≤ 0.075). Afterward, the resultant gel was poured into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, sealed, and reacted at 443 K for 72 h statically. The as-made sample was gleaned by separation and washed thoroughly with deionized water. The final product was dried in an air oven at 373 K overnight. Similarly, Na_TS-1 was fabricated by the following recipe: 1 SiO2 : 0.125 NaOH : 0.125 TPABr : 0.075 Ti(C3H7O)4: 35 H2O. It should be noted that in the following experiment, the adopted silica source was silica gel (Ludox-AS40) without a pre-hydrolysis procedure. Before some tests, the as-made sample was calcined at 823 K in the air for 6 h in a muffle furnace to remove OSDA species. 2.2 Characterization methods The crystal phase of obtained sample was confirmed on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer in Bragg-Brentano geometry, equipped with copper radiation source (wavelength λ = 1.5418 Å) and energy-resolved LynxXEye detector working at voltage: 40 kV, current: 40 mA. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern for obtained TS-1 phase verification was collected in the 2Theta angle range of 5–50° with step size: 0.02° at collection speed: 0.1°/s. The PXRD dataset for structure refinement was collected on an STOE STADI/P diffractometer with a monochromatic copper radiation source (λ = 1.540598 Å) equipped with a Mythen detector in Debye-Scherrer geometry, and operated at voltage: 40 kV and current: 40 mA. In addition, the whole PXRD pattern was merged by three different data segments, which were collected with different exposure. The FT-IR spectra of the samples were conducted on a Nicolet IS5 with the wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1. Before measurements, the powder was mixed thoroughly with KBr. The N2 sorption was performed on an ASAP 2020 HD88 apparatus at 77 K. Before tests, the calcined sample was degassed at 573 K for 4 h. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were evaluated on Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) model, respectively. Additionally, the total pore volume and micropore volume were deduced by the t-plot method by the dataset of relative pressure (P/P0) around 0.05. The morphology of Au-coated TS-1 was monitored by an FEI Quanta FEG 250. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image, selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern, and element mapping spectra were obtained on a field emission Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin. Before observation, the powder was ground with absolute ethanol in an agate mortar. Then, the suspension was dispersed on a carbon-coated mesh grid for further observation. The inorganic composition of Si, O, Ti, and Na of obtained sample was analyzed on an Agilent 725 inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of Ti species in different samples were performed on a Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha apparatus. The UV–Vis spectra were measured on a Shimadzu UV-3600 plus in the wavelength range of 200–800 nm with reflection mode. The UV-Raman spectra were carried on a HORIBA HR Evolution equipped with a 244 nm laser source and collected in the range of 200–1400 cm−1. Thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) of organic species was analyzed by a Hitachi TG-DTA7300 within 323–1073 K at a rate of 10 K/min in air. The liquid 13C NMR spectra were conducted on a JNM-ECZ400S with the TMS as the reference. The solid-state 29Si and 1H→13C cross-polar (CP) magic-angle spinning (MAS) NMR spectra were performed on a Bruker WB400 spectrometer. The active radical in the reacted systems involving H2O2 solution was captured with 20 μL 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) in an ice bath. Then, a small amount of the above mixture was loaded in a 0.9 mm capillary and monitored on an electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer Bruker EMX-10/12. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation Typically, NH3·H2O solution (0.034 mol, 25% wt.) and H2O2 (0.034 mol, 30% wt.) were mixed in the presence of cyclohexanone (0.023 mol) with tert‑butanol as the solvent, and TS-1 catalyst (0.35 g) was loaded into a 100 mL three-necked flask. The mixture was reacted at 345 K with vigorous stirring. It should be noted that, during the reaction procedure, the required amount of NH3·H2O and H2O2 were slowly injected by a peristaltic pump in 90 min. Then, the reaction time was prolonged to another 120 min. After the reaction, the mixture was centrifuged. The obtained products were monitored on gas chromatography (Agilent GC 7890B), which was equipped with a hydrogen flame detector and an Agilent HP-5 capillary chromatography columns (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm). The conversion of cyclohexanone and product selectivity was analyzed by the internal standard method. Calculation of conversion, selectivity, TON, and TOF was listed as follows. (1) Conversion of cyclohexanone ( % ) = Moles of cyclohexanone coverted Moles of cyclohexanone introduced × 100 (2) Selectivity of cyclohexanone oxime ( % ) = Moles of cyclohexanone oxime produced Moles of cyclohexanone converted × 100 (3) Turnover number ( TON ) = Moles of cyclohexanone oxime produced Moles of Ti active site × dispersion Turnover frequency ( TOF ) = Moles of cyclohexanone oxime produced Moles of Ti active site × dispersion × reaction time (4) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of titanium silicalite-1 Fig. 1 a, 1b shows the channel system and the PXRD patterns of as-made TS-1 and Na_TS-1, respectively. Compared with the hkl reflection positions, the pattern indicates a typical MFI topology. In addition, the Pawley fitting results suggest the general reflection conditions: 0kl: k + l = 2n, hk0: h = 2n, implying the obtained zeolites were orthorhombic phase. Therefore, the space group of the as-made sample was deduced as Pnma (No. 62), with the following unit cell parameters: a = 20.096 Å, b = 19.922 Å, and c = 13.399 Å. Specifically, there are 12 independent tetrahedral (T) sites and 26 oxygen atoms in an asymmetric unit in the MFI framework (Fig. 1a). These atoms constructed a unique three-dimensional channel system: the 10-MR (MR, membered ring, pore size: 5.3 Å by 5.6 Å) straight channels along [010] perpendicular to the 10-MR (5.1 Å by 5.5 Å) sinusoidal channels along [100] (Fig. 1a). To investigate the status of the Ti species, the Fourier transformed infrared (FT-IR) spectra of as-made TS-1 were performed (Fig. 1c). The band located at 960 cm−1 was ascribed to typical stretching vibration of Si-O-Ti-bonds [10] in the zeolite framework. The band at 3440 cm−1 was attributed to the silanol nests in the zeolite framework. As evaluated by N2 sorption isotherms (Fig. 1d, Table S1), all calcined samples exhibit typical I sorption features [48]. Additionally, TS-1 showed an initial steep curve above 100 cm3/g at a low relative pressure (P/P0= 0.05), with a BET surface area of about 429 m2/g, which is higher than that of Na_TS-1 (327 m2/g). As revealed by the SEM images (Fig. 1e), the as-made bulky zeolite display a uniform twinned cubic morphology with a crystal size of about ∼10 μm. Different from other samples, a subtle hysteresis loop was observed in the sorption isotherms of the Na_TS-1, suggesting the formation of mesoporous structure (around 2.5 nm), mostly due to the stacking mode of irregular zeolite crystallites (Fig. 1f). The pore size distribution also manifests the different Ti substituted MFI zeolite framework still retains the original micropore structure (Fig. S1, Fig. S2). Furthermore, from a small zeolite crystallite (Fig. 2 a, 2c inset), the well-ordered micropore structure was captured in the high-resolution TEM images (Fig. 2a, 2c), along [100] and [010] zone axis (as shown in inset SAED of encircled area), respectively. Notably, uniform elemental distribution of Ti, O, Si were found in the element mapping of both TS-1 and Na_TS-1 (Fig. 2b, 2d). No apparent aggregated TiO x clusters in nanoscale were observed in low- or high-resolution TEM images. 3.2 The preferential location of incorporated Ti atoms in titanium silicalite-1 To investigate the specific location of substituted Ti atoms, the Rietveld refinement of as-made titanium silicalite-1 was performed. The empty MFI framework deposited in IZA-SC was selected as the starting point. After optimizing the structure model, the zeolite structure was completed by the elemental analysis results. In the structural refinement routine, once the occluded guest species were located, then the exact elemental composition of each framework T site was set flexible to refine. Then the occupancy of Si in all tetrahedral sites was released and refined within the range of 0∼1.0. If the refined occupancy was less than 1.0, the T sites were treated as mixed Si/Ti sites, and the Ti content was equally assigned with fixed composition constraint Si+Ti = 1.0, correspondingly. In the refinement process, the Ti substituted zeolite framework is optimized as well. The Rietveld refinement of TS-1 gives a rational fitting against the experimental data with converged indexes: Rp : 3.16%, Rwp : 4.95%, and GOF: 1.95 (Table S2). Due to the high quality of the large-sized TS-1, we were able to identify the Ti atoms mainly located at T2, T4, and T11 (Fig. 3 a, Fig. 3b, Table S3). Similarly, the Ti enriched T sites in Na_TS-1 were found to be T4, T7, and T12 (Fig. 3c, Fig. 3d, Table S4). These results unveiled here indicate the specific locations of the Ti atom were not random but can be significantly influenced by the synthetic conditions. 3.3 The comparison of Ti chemical environment in TS-1 and Na_TS-1 Upon further inspection of incorporated T atoms, the origin of high-quality TS-1 is investigated. Different from the typical synthetic condition of Na_TS-1, the pre-hydrolysis and high temperature treated silica source showed a low solubility in the synthetic gel of TS-1. This phenomenon results in a small number of zeolite nuclei at the initial crystallization stage. Then, the limited quantity of nuclei with abundant nutrients evolved into a large-sized TS-1 crystal [49,50]. It has been generally accepted that charge vacancy defects in zeolite formation are due to the charge balancing of positive guest TPA+ cations by Si-O − in siliceous MFI structure. This unique stoichiometric interaction between one organic cation and a Si-O− group in siliceous monomer and/or oligomer left other silanol groups free [51]. As expected, solid-state 29Si MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 4 ) clearly showed that the TS-1 has a higher content of silanol defects ((SiO)3Si-OH, Q3: 25%) than that (Q3: 16%) of Na_TS-1. In the TPA system, due to the steric effect of OSDA, a large amount of residual silanol group structure defects facilitate grafting Ti (IV) species in the zeolite framework. In the Na-TPA system, the silanol group was mainly balanced by Na+, leading to a sharp decrease in the amount of the Si-OH group (Fig. 4), which was further confirmed by FT-IR (Fig. 1c). Eventually, the different synthetic conditions involving zeolite crystallization and Ti insertion manner bring about the different Ti locations in TS-1. As shown in UV–Vis spectra (Fig. 5 a), there is an adsorption band at 210 nm and 260 nm in the different Ti-containing TS-1 that can be assigned to the framework tetra-coordinated and multiply (penta- or hexa-) coordinated Ti species, respectively [52–56]. Notably, such similar band at 250–290 nm was also captured in the Ti-YNU-2, a highly reactive Ti-containing multi-dimensional MSE framework [57], which composed a large amount of penta- or hexa- coordinated Ti species [56]. Raman spectra were collected using a 244 nm laser source (Fig. 5d), the samples show two distinct patterns. For TS-1, the sharp resonances were located at 490, 530, and 1125 cm−1 (Fig. 5d), which could be ascribed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration mode of Si-O-Ti structures [14,16], respectively. For Na_TS-1, the aforementioned features were absent. To interpret the chemical nature of incorporated Ti, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was adopted to explore the binding energy of Ti species. Generally, the XPS spectra of TS-1 exhibit the peaks at 533, 460, 285, and 104 eV, which correspond to the core level energy of O 1 s, Ti 2p, C 1 s, and Si 2p (Fig. 5b), respectively. Besides, the resonance at 1080 eV for Na 1 s was found in Na_TS-1 (Fig. 5e), which is in line with the chemical elemental analysis results (Table S2). For TS-1, the high-resolution Ti 2p spectra were fitted with two resonances at 464.36 (2p 1/2) and 458.65 eV (2p 3/2) (Fig. 5c) for Ti(IV) species, suggesting that the Ti species incorporated into the zeolite framework mainly in the single site form. On the contrary, the peaks of Ti in Na_TS-1 given a lower value at 464.25 (2p 1/2) and 458.55 eV (2p 3/2) (Fig. 5f), respectively. There is a 0.11 eV bias between TS-1 and Na_TS-1. It is known that Ti species always exhibit tetra- and hexa-coordinated structures in the siliceous framework [43,52-56]. According to the previous reports [53–56], the Ti species in the zeolite framework is generally accepted as an open active hexa-coordinated (SiO)3Ti(OH)1(H2O)2 [56] and/or (SiO)2Ti(OH)2(H2O)2 and closed tetra-coordinated Ti(OSi)4. Therefore, the 0.11 eV was assigned to hexa-coordinated Ti species (tetra-coordinated Ti center with two dative bonds with water molecules), for the electronegative difference between Ti and O atoms. Compared to the tetra-coordinated structure, the electron density of the hexa-coordinated Ti center decreases, implying the higher knockout value of electrons. This open hexa-coordinated structure in TS-1 with water molecules can be found at 697 cm−1 in the 244 nm UV-Raman spectra (Fig. 5d) which is in line with the previous report [54]. To probe the coordination status of Ti species during the reaction. The catalyst contact with neutral H2O2 solution was performed (Fig. S3), a new adsorption band at 874 cm−1 in 244 nm Raman spectra are formed on the TS-1. According to the previously reported calculations [38], the vibration of -O-O- group of H2O2 (876 cm−1) [16,58] and Ti-O-O-H (885.2 cm−1) in TS-1 is very close and should not differ significantly. In this sense, this band could be tentatively assigned to a labile “end-on” structured Ti species (Ti-O-O-H). However, a more stable form of “side-on” υ(O-O) [16] at 840 cm−1 is not observed in this experiment. In addition, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was performed to further confirm the active species in reaction, the typical split of two central resonances (Fig. S4) indicates the superoxide radical (O2 −) in the catalytic systems [59–61]. 3.4 Reaction kinetics and molecular insights of cyclohexanone ammoximation over TS-1 To clarify the TS-1 nature in cyclohexanone ammoximation at the molecular scale, the spent ex-situ catalysts were extracted and analyzed at different reaction stages. Generally, the TS-1 showed a conversion of 53% and a selectivity of 98%. Notably, when the catalyst was replaced by Na_TS-1, the system showed a very low conversion of 42% and product selectivity of 19% (Fig. 6 a) under identical reaction conditions. The turnover numbers (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) of different TS-1 catalysts were calculated to evaluate the intrinsic nature of the active sites. Compared to the Na_TS-1, the catalytic profile in TON and TOF of TS-1 (Fig. 6b) was facilitated to investigate its catalytic mechanism. To address the significant difference in the catalytic performance of TS-1 and Na_TS-1, the catalyst adopted in the reaction were investigated by FT-IR, UV–Vis, UV-Raman, and PXRD Rietveld refinement. Generally, the ammonia oxidation of cyclohexanone to its oxime undergoes two crucial steps [62,63]: i) the activation of Ti species with H2O2, and ii) the cascade oxidation of ammonia and ketone molecules on the activated zeolite moiety. In the early days, there is a debate on the reaction pathway (imine oxidation or hydroxylamine process) in the synthesis of oxime over TS-1 [64–66]. It is known that oxime can be made by ketone and hydroxylamine even without the presence of the catalyst. A bulky molecule (i.e., 4‑tert-butylcyclohexanone) was adopted in the probe reaction, which cannot enter the zeolite channel system. However, the bulky molecule is still transformed into the product in the presence of hydroxylamine [67]. Therefore, the imine oxidation mechanism is ruled out [68]. On this basis, the reaction kinetics with the power-law model was proposed [69]. Afterward, an improved reaction kinetic model was put forward with a continuous flow microfluidic reaction system [68]. From reaction kinetics, we found that the reaction rate is determined by the concentration of H2O2 and NH3·H2O and independent of cyclohexanone (Fig. S5). Based on the conversion of cyclohexanone at different temperatures (Fig. S5g), the linear function of ln(R)−1/T can be obtained (Fig. S5h). Finally, the pre-exponential factor A and activation energy Ea was determined as: 0.335×1012 L/g/min and 74.28 kJ/mol, which is quite close to the reported results of 1.10×1012 L/g/min and 93.2 kJ/mol [68]. According to the reaction kinetics, the concentration of ketone is not the rate-determining factor [68]. As a crucial reactant, the role of cyclohexanone in the whole reaction remains elusive. To gain further insights into the reaction at the molecular scale, the cyclohexanone and the final product loaded TS-1 at different reaction stages were extracted and analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction crystallography, respectively. According to the FT-IR (Fig. S6) and 1H→13C CP solid-state MAS NMR spectra (Fig. S7), the organic species were entrapped and maintained their integrity in the zeolite cavity. Compared with liquid 13C NMR spectra, the difference of chemical shift in the solid-state MAS NMR spectra was attributed to the anisotropic effect. Due to the boiling point difference of guest organic species, the quantity of cyclohexanone and oxime molecule occluded in the MFI host was deduced by TG results (Fig. S8): 2.44 and 2.06, respectively. Then the PXRD refinement (Fig. S9, Fig. S10) against the experimental data was performed. After generating an electron density difference map, the initial coordinates of cyclohexanone and oxime were completed by simulated annealing routine in each sample, respectively. The refinement ends up with a reasonable fit to the data with converged indexes Rexp : 1.87%, Rp : 3.32%, Rwp : 5.05%, GOF: 2.68 (Table S2). It is found that the cyclohexanone and oxime molecules (Fig. S11, Table S5, and S6) were located at the intersection node of MFI and showed a classic host-guest interaction with a rational distance of about 3 Å. The experimental results unveiled here may provide a starting point for the forthcoming research in this field. 3.5 Putative catalytic mechanism On this basis, a plausible hydroxylamine route-based reaction mechanism was proposed for TS-1 (Scheme 1 , i). Initially, the open hexa-coordinated Ti species was activated by the oxygen species of hydroperoxide. One –OOH group was coordinated with the central Ti atom via ligand exchange process to form a peroxo species Ti-O-OH [56,70]. According to previous reports [58,70,71], this structure was stabilized by forming a Ti-containing five-membered ring with the adjacent hydroxyl group. Consequently, the ammonia molecule (-H-NH2) was coordinated with the peroxide group in the Ti containing a five-membered ring and converted to an NH2OH (Scheme 1, ii). Finally, in the cascade reaction, the ketone compound was transformed via nucleophilic reaction into the target product and water (Scheme 1, iii). On the contrary, the Na_TS-1 showed low efficiency in the conversion of cyclohexanone to the target product, which was mainly restrained by the location and coordinated status of Ti species (as unveiled by FT-IR, UV-Vis, and UV Raman results) (Fig. S6). Then, the Na_TS-1 washed with H2SO4 solution was performed, after intensive attempts, the post-treated structure still exhibits almost identical FT-IR spectra (Fig. S12) to the original one. In addition, the low catalytic efficiency of the post-treated Na_TS-1 cannot be recovered to the level of TS-1, which differs from the results in the previous report [72]. In this work, the unique phenomena also suggest that the closed Ti species in Na_TS-1 is hardly converted to a highly active moiety (Scheme 1). Due to the comparable Ti content with different location and coordination statuses, the TS-1 exhibits an efficient catalytic performance than that of Na_TS-1. In the reaction process, despite the two different molecules occupying a similar position in the MFI cavity, the oxime presents a distinct orientation and interaction sites from that of the ketone. In other words, the two crucial intermediates from ex-situ samples unveiled here also imply that the ketone converted into the final product undergo a complicated series of reaction steps. Notably, for the specific location of Ti sites, both ketone substrates and oxime all show an overwhelming spatial intimacy to the Ti species, which might clarify the internal connection between preferred Ti location and high catalytic efficiency of TS-1. Conclusions As unveiled by PXRD crystallography, the Ti sites are mainly located at T2, T4, and T11 in high-quality TS-1 prepared by the pre-hydrolysis silica source strategy, which is different from the sites: T4, T7, and T12 found in Na_TS-1. Compared to the closed structure ((SiO)4Ti) in Na_TS-1, by combined spectroscopy methods, the active species in TS-1 was confirmed as a hexa-coordinated Ti with an open structure (SiO)2Ti(OH)2(H2O)2. Note the structure difference between TS-1 and Na_TS-1, these open structures of TS-1 shown an enhanced catalytic conversion of cyclohexanone to oxime (conversion: 53% vs 42%, product selectivity: 98% vs 19%). From the TS-1 extracted from different reaction stages, the ketone and its product occluded in the zeolite host exhibiting an overwhelming spatial intimacy to the Ti species, which might account for the high catalytic efficiency of TS-1. Overall, these results clarified unequivocally that precise interpretation of such Ti locations associated with guest molecules will allow rational chosen the most effective catalyst for ammoximation reaction become reality. coredata.dc:description: The discovery of titanium silicalite-1(TS-1) is a milestone in the development of heterogeneous catalysts for the eco-benign and mild catalytic oxidation process. However, the interpretation of specific Ti location and its role in oxidation is severely hindered due to the limited crystal size of as-synthesized TS-1. Here, a high quality TS-1 (ca. 10 μm) was successfully fabricated by the pre-hydrolysis silica source strategy. As evidenced by powder X-ray diffraction crystallography, the preferred Ti locations were mainly found at T2, T4, and T11 in Ti-containing MFI framework. Combining multiple spectroscopy methods (i.e., FT-IR, UV–Vis, and UV Raman) and the reaction kinetics, the active center in TS-1 was demonstrated as an exposed site of hexa-coordinated titainum species. Furthermore, the powder X-ray crystallography also revealed that the ketone and oxime adsorbed in the zeolite host with intense host-guest interaction of framework oxygen atoms, and exhibiting an overwhelming spatial intimacy to the Ti species at the molecular scale. This unique phenomenon affords a plausible interpretation for the oxime reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Insights into the role of titanium sites in cyclohexanone ammoximation over titanium silicalite-1
